title: High Street at 'breaking point' as top chain stores fight for survival
text:
The High Street is at 'breaking point' and many of the country's biggest chains are in a fight for survival, says a major study.

Changing consumer habits, an unfair business rates regime and rising staff costs are hitting the UK's biggest chains leading to more store closures than ever before, according to research by professional services firm A&M.

Profit margins in stores have fallen in the past eight years from 8.8 per cent to 4.1 per cent, while costs have soared by close to 11 per cent in the past five years.

Changing consumer habits, an unfair business rates regime and rising staff costs are hitting the UK's biggest chains leading to more store closures than ever before

Traditional bricks-and-mortar shops have also suffered because consumer spending online has risen fourfold since 2008.

The report estimates that Britain's 150 largest retailers, including supermarkets, have 20 per cent more store space than they would like, which has fuelled closures and insolvencies.

Richard Fleming, managing director of A&M, said: 'Breaking point is indeed upon us. The whole retail sector is going through a seismic model shift.

For larger UK retailers, store-based profit margins have halved in the last eight years.

'Most of the UK's biggest retail brands are in the midst of a fight for survival.

'We have already seen some high-profile casualties, and many more are on life support.'

The report's authors predicted a High Street with smaller stores, acting as a shop window for a larger range of products sold online.
